headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to Kraft Foods Fourth Quarter 2010 and Year End Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about one hour including remarks by Kraft management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'd now lik
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to Kraft Foods Fourth Quarter 2010 and Year End Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about one hour including remarks by Kraft management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Chris Jakubik, Vice President, Investor Relations for Kraft. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. With me are Irene Rosenfeld, our Chairman and CEO; and Tim McLevish, our Chief Financial Officer. Earlier today we put out our earnings release was sent out earlier today and is available on our website, kraftfoo
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. With me are Irene Rosenfeld, our Chairman and CEO; and Tim McLevish, our Chief Financial Officer. Earlier today we put out our earnings release was sent out earlier today and is available on our website, kraftfoodscompany.com. 
As you know, during this call we will be making forward-looking statements about the company's performance. These statements are based on how we see things today. Actual results may differ materially due to risks and uncertainties, so please refer to the cautionary statements and risk factors contained in our 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more details on our forward-looking statements. Some of today's prepared remarks will include non-GAAP financial measures. And you can find the GAAP- to non-GAAP reconciliations within our news release at the back of the slide presentation.
Let me now turn it over to Irene.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris, and good afternoon. Tim and I will start to the highlights of our fourth quarter results. That provide our 2011 outlook and we'll take your questions.Our Q4 results reflected a strong finish to 2010. From a total company perspective, we d
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris, and good afternoon. Tim and I will start to the highlights of our fourth quarter results. That provide our 2011 outlook and we'll take your questions.
Our Q4 results reflected a strong finish to 2010. From a total company perspective, we delivered high quality top and bottom line results in a more difficult environment than any of us has anticipated. We delivered a good balance between volume/mix and pricing despite the significant pricing actions taken since August to offset input costs. In fact, in our base business, vol/mix growth more that 2/3 of our top line growth in both the  fourth quarter and for the full year. At the same time, we continued to invest behind our Power Brands. Advertising and consumer spending in the quarter on our base business was in line with very strong levels in Q4 2009 and up double digit for the full year.  And finally, we realized significant benefits from productivity improvements and overhead cost savings.
Our Q4 momentum was broad-based, with contributions from every geography. In Developing Markets, we once again delivered double-digit revenue growth. Asia Pacific and Latin America led the region, while the trend in our CEEMA business improved with high single-digit growth. In Europe, we delivered another quarter of solid revenue gains with growth in each of our key categories. In addition, despite sharply higher input costs, Europe continue to expand operating margin.
We were especially pleased that North America had a strong finish to the year, with revenue improving sequentially. In fact, top line growth was the strongest we have seen in some time. This was driven by significantly better volumes versus the prior year as we stepped up merchandising activity and introduced several new marketing campaigns. 
Of course, one of our key goals in 2010 was the integration of Cadbury, and I'm pleased to report that it's progressing well. In fact, it's running ahead of our investment case. That said, in the fourth quarter and for the full year, Cadbury revenue growth was somewhat below our expectations. In addition to the inventory destocking we told you about several months ago, the Gum and Candy categories were disproportionally hurt by the weak consumer environment in a number of major markets. Chocolate, however, was ahead of plan, fueled by increased marketing support.
Looking ahead, the inventory destocking is behind us. We'll build on our strong market shares and we're investing in marketing and innovation to reinvigorate growth in the Gum and Candy categories. On the bottom line, the earnings dilution from the acquisition was $0.11, approximately $0.05 better than our expectations. This was driven by our combination of earlier delivery of cost synergies, as well as lower interest expense and share dilution. What's more, we significantly increased advertising and marketing support in key markets, which drove market share growth in all categories, including Gum and Candy. More importantly, we now expect the Cadbury acquisition will turn earnings accretive in 2011. That is accretive to operating EPS, not just to cash EPS, as we had previously guided.
In terms of the balance sheet, our focus on working capital has already begun to pay dividends. Cash generated from the Cadbury business more than doubled versus the 2010 plan and was well in excess of their historical levels. This was a key contributor to the lower leverage on our year end balance sheet. The infusion of Cadbury talent into our organization is all so going well. I'm really pleased with the retention of top talent, and as I've noted before, about a third of our top 400 executives came to us from Cadbury. I'm very proud of how well our people have come together as a team with a shared commitment to a performance-driven, values-led company.
Finally, a quick update on the Cadbury cost synergies. As I said earlier, we're running ahead of plan. In 2010, we realized about 25% of the $750 million in targeted cost synergies. That's better than our earlier estimate of 15%. And we remain on track to deliver about 70% of our synergies in 2011.
On the cost side, we've spent about 40% of the estimated $1.5 billion in Integration Program costs. That's somewhat lower than our prior estimate of 50%, but that's mainly due to timing. 
Let me now turn it over to Tim to discuss our fourth quarter results in more detail.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Irene, and good afternoon. Let me start by saying that we're quite encouraged by what we saw in our fourth quarter performance. As I'll outline over the next few minutes, our results were in line with our expectations. We posted stronger operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Irene, and good afternoon. Let me start by saying that we're quite encouraged by what we saw in our fourth quarter performance. As I'll outline over the next few minutes, our results were in line with our expectations. We posted stronger operating gains from our base business, offset by rapidly rising input costs and the persistently weak consumer environment in many markets. Now let me provide some details, starting with our top line.
Organic net revenue from the combined business grew 5.7%, as focused investments drove continued strong growth in our Power Brands in every region. In fact, these brands collectively grew 8% in the fourth quarter. In the Kraft base business, organic revenues increased 6.5% driven by 4.6 points from vol/mix and 1.9 points from pricing. The strong vol/mix gains are encouraging, as we raised prices in many categories to offset sharply higher input costs. 
In the Cadbury business, organic revenues rose 2.2%, which was clearly lower than we would expect on an ongoing basis. Growth was tempered again this quarter by our decision to normalize trade inventories in certain markets. This reduced Cadbury's overall top line growth by about 60 basis points. In addition, the Gum and Candy categories were soft. This was a result of economic conditions leading to weaker consumption by team by the heaviest consumers. As Irene said, we have solid plans in place for 2011 to reinvigorate consumption in these important categories.
Turning to profit, our operating interim margin, excluding acquisition and Integration Program costs, was 11.6%. In our Kraft base business, operating income margin fell slightly to 11.1%. There were several factors at work here. On the positive side, we posted strong gains from our productivity programs. And we have significantly lower overhead costs versus the prior year. Offsetting these, we continued to increase investment behind our brands. But the biggest factor in the fourth quarter was the rapid escalation of input costs. This gross tempered both gross margin and outline margins in every region during the quarter.
To give you some perspective, let's look at the trend in year-over-year changes for our Kraft base business. As you can see on Slide 8 in both the fourth quarter 2009 and first quarter 2010, these costs were favorable year-over-year. During these quarters, we benefited from the carryover of 2009 pricing actions. Pricing caught up with input cost levels, and hence, our gross margins were stronger in those quarters. In fact, our gross margins in Q4 2009 were the highest they have been since the fourth quarter of 2004. 
During the second quarter of 2010, the year-over-year impact of input costs was roughly flat, but the trend has continued to deteriorate since then. As we told you in our Q3 call, we had already started to take pricing across several categories. And we knew that margins would be under pressure in the near-term. But even those actions were insufficient, as input costs continued to increase sharply during the fourth quarter. In fact, Q4 input costs in our base business were up nearly $500 million and our margins suffered accordingly. 
Our current expectation is that input costs will remain high throughout 2011. As a result, we're now in the process of implementing further pricing actions to reflect these higher input cost levels. We expect that pricing will continue to lag input cost in the first half of the year. This will pressure gross margins. However, they should recover in the back half of the year as prices and costs become better aligned.
Turning to EPS, let me walk you through the bridge for the quarter.Let's start with Q4 of 2009 where we were $0.48. $0.04 of that came from the divested Pizza business. We also spent $0.03 on Cadbury acquisition-related costs and financing fees. So from a year ago base of $0.47, our operating EPS was essentially flat at $0.46 and in line with our expectations. 
Our Kraft base business had another strong quarter, delivering $0.06 of operating gains versus the prior year. This was offset by a combination of losses on some small divestitures, unfavorable FX and asset impairments. Cadbury operating earnings contributed $0.15 to EPS, that's a little ahead of expectations mainly from the early delivery of cost synergies. Below the line, interest and shares were higher due to funding the Cadbury acquisition. This was offset in part from the proceeds from the pizza sale. Interest expense also came in higher due to cost related to the early retirement of debt. This is offset by the benefits of the lower than anticipated tax rate.
For the full year, I'd like to highlight two key points: First, improved vol/mix, productivity and overhead savings grew 22% of operating gains in our Kraft base business, and we did this while continuing to increase investment in our Power Brands across the portfolio; second, we delivered on our commitments to earn at least $2 of operating EPS this year, and we did so in a high quality manner. 
I'll take a few minutes after share highlights of our business results by geography.  In North America, we made good progress within a weak consumer environment. On a combined basis, organic net revenues grew 3.3%, up from 1% in the third quarter. In addition, top line growth was broad-based, with revenue increasing in all business units but one. In fact, we used share in more than half the businesses in Q4. 
We continue to invest behind our Power Brands, and they responded by growing 5%. There were many stars in the quarter. Here are just a view that single to double-digit: Oreo, Ritz , Wispa, Maxwell House, Planters and Macaroni and Cheese. In the Kraft base business, organic revenues grew 4.1%, which was the best top line performance in more than two years. Higher merchandising and the successful multibrand huddle to  fight Huddle to Fight Hunger campaign with the vol/mix gains at 2.4 percentage points. 
Pricing, net of promotion, grow an additional 1.7 points to the growth. Cadbury organic net revenues, however, were disappointing, declining 6.1% in the quarter. This reflected two headwinds: Difficult comparisons in Gum against major Trident and Stride product launches in the prior quarter, and tough comparisons with last year's strong shipments of Halls due to the H1N1 flu season. Both of these were anticipated in our plan. In addition, there was heavy promotional spending in major product launch by a Gum competitor in 2010.
Looking ahead, we expect the business to regain momentum in Q1, with the launch of Trident Vitality and Strides  Spark, as well as continued strong growth in Dentyne.
Next let's look at profitability. On a combined basis, our operating income margin in North America was 14.2%. Our Cadbury business posted strong operating income margin of 22.8%, driven by productivity gains and improved product mix. In our Kraft base business, IO margin declined to 13.5%. This was largely driven by timing. First, the increase in input cost outpaced pricing and productivity gains. And second, our merchandising and promotional program was significantly more skewed to the fourth quarter this year versus the prior year.
Looking forward, in the face of substantial input cost inflation, we're in the process of implementing another round of price increases in our North American portfolio. While this will pressure margins in the near term, we'll use the combination of pricing, productivity and overhead savings to improve margins for the full year.
In Europe, combined organic revenues increased 1.6%, fueled by our Power Brands, which collectively grew 6% across the region. In our Kraft base business, momentum mentioned continued as organic revenues grew 2.2% overall, driven by two points from vol/mix gains. Moreover, revenue growth was broad-based, with increases in each of our key categories. 
Chocolate grew low single digits, driven by strong in-store marketing activities, promotional programs and new products. Toblerone and Milka each delivered high single-digit growth. Our Biscuit business grew, driven by the strength of our Power Brands, including double-digit gains by both Oreo and Belvita. The strong momentum in the Chocobakery platform also drove vol/mix gains. 
Weak economic conditions, particularly in Benelux and Southern Europe, and lower pricing partially offset these gains. Coffee grew low single digits, driven by pricing in response to higher input costs. On-demand market expansion and more brewer sales drove midteens growth in Tassimo. Cheese grew high single digits, primarily reflecting a successful marketing campaign and new product launches of Philadelphia.
In our Cadbury business, organic net revenues were essentially flat, solid growth in the U.K. was offset by weak Gum and Candy markets in Southern Europe. Operating income margins in Europe rose to 11.1% on a combined basis. This reflected productivity, overhead savings and improved product mix. 
In our Kraft base business, IO margin improved by 160 basis points to 9.8%, while our Cadbury business also reported solid OI margin of 14.5% in the quarter. In Europe, as in North America, input costs are rising significantly and we're pricing accordingly. In fact, we've already implemented or announced price increases in the large majority of our European portfolio. That said, in the fourth quarter, the contribution from pricing trailed input cost inflation and we're  in the process of implementing another round of price increases.
Turning now to Developing Markets, combined organic net revenue increased 13.6%, fueled by 18% growth in our Power Brands. This was very strong growth even after adjusting for accounting calendar changes that added 3.7 percentage points. Increased market investments drove growth of 17.3% in the Kraft base business and strong share gains in priority markets in key categories. 
In Latin America, organic revenues rose by more than 20%, propelled by strong gains in Brazil and the Andean countries. Power Brands grew more than 25%, led by Oreo, Club Social, Lacta and Tang. 
In Asia Pacific, organic revenues grew 30% due to strong vol/mix gains in China, Indonesia and the Philippines. Power Brands, collectively, grew more than 50%, led by Oreo, Tiger Biskuat and Tang. And in CEEMA, key markets are improving, although market conditions remained weak. This region delivered organic revenue growth in the high single digits, led by gains in Ukraine, Russia and the Middle East. Power Brands collectively grew 8%, led by Tang and Toca. 
In our Cadbury business, organic revenues rose a solid 6.7%, including a negative impact of 1.4 percentage points from normalizing trade inventories. Growth came from gains across all categories. Our operating income margin in Developing Markets was 12.6%. In our Kraft base business, profit margins rose to 11.9%, while OI margins from our Cadbury business were also strong at 13.9%. Overall, overhead leverage and pricing offset sharply higher input costs.
Finally, I'd like to update you on our deleveraging plant, which is formerly on track. Over the past 12 months, our net debt has decreased by about $4  billion to $26.2 billion. A key enabler of this has been strong free cash flow from operations. Adjusting for the sale of the Pizza business, we generated about $3.3 million in free cash flow. This reflected solid progress in working capital efficiency and the Kraft base business and a significant reduction in working capital in the Cadbury business. As a result, we've been able to take several important actions this year to reduce debt. 
As we intended at the time of the deal, we paid back the acquisition bridge loan with proceeds from the sale of the North American Pizza business. We settled the $500 million August maturity with cash from operations, and we repurchased $1.5 billion in debt with cash from operations and short-term commercial paper. 
Looking forward, we're on tract to achieve a debt-to-EBITDA ratio approaching 3x within the next 12 months. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call back to Irene, who will discuss our outlook for 2011.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. As you've seen, we delivered solid financial results in 2010, and we entered 2011 with broad-based momentum for three key reasons: First, we're firmly committed to continuing to invest behind our Power Brands, our innovation pipeline and reve
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. As you've seen, we delivered solid financial results in 2010, and we entered 2011 with broad-based momentum for three key reasons: First, we're firmly committed to continuing to invest behind our Power Brands, our innovation pipeline and revenue synergies from the Cadbury integration. These investments are critical to put protecting our share and delivering long-term growth. In fact, we just began to scratch the surface on the approximately $1 billion in revenue synergies enabled by Cadbury. As expected, these synergies were modest in 2010, but they'll ramp up over the next three years old. 
Second, our Developing Markets business continues to generate strong double-digit growth, and as a result of the Cadbury acquisition, it's an even greater part of our portfolio. So we're well-positioned to continue to capitalize on our larger footprint in this fast growing region.
Third, we have strong cost savings programs. On our base business, productivity and overhead efficiencies will drive significant gains. These savings, along with the Cadbury synergies, will expand operating margin.
At the same time, the operating environment continues to be challenging. Unemployment rates remain high. Consumer confidence is weak, and government austerity programs are planned in some markets. In the face of this consumer weakness, input costs continued to rise, and that will require additional pricing. That said, we remain cautiously optimistic. Cautious about what we can't control, but optimistic about what we can. Cautious about the consumer environment, but highly optimistic about Kraft's market position and strong momentum. 
Specifically, in 2011, we expect to deliver organic net revenue growth of more than 5% or approximately 4%, excluding the year-over-year impact of calendar changes. However, we're taking a more measured deal at this time of the drivers of this growth, namely more pricing and less vol/mix.
On the bottom line, we're targeting operating EPS growth measured view of 11% to 13%. This guidance is higher than our long-term goal of 9% to 11%, but slightly less bullish than our previous target, reflecting our more conservative view of vol/mix. In some, our business fundamentals are strong, with share gains across most categories and most markets. 
Focused investments behind Power Brands in key categories are driving solid, sustainable growth. Cadbury is on track to be accretive in year 2. And in a challenging consumer environment, we are confident in our ability to deliver strong financial results in the top tier of our peer group. 
Now we'd be happy to take your questions.

So we expect additional in 2011. I would expect to see that input costs are up high single digits relative to 2010 in '11.

componenttext: I guess, first, a quick one is, I saw that the contribution of price mix this quarter decelerated from the third quarter. I know you've been kind of taking pricing as the quarter went on, was that just on merchandising that was part of that in the fourth quarter?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, Andrew, it's mostly a function of timing versus the prior year. If you recall, Q4 2009 was rather wide in terms of merchandising and promotion. As you recall, we have some challenges with one of our key customers. Q4 2010 was much heavier. We ha
componenttext: Actually, Andrew, it's mostly a function of timing versus the prior year. If you recall, Q4 2009 was rather wide in terms of merchandising and promotion. As you recall, we have some challenges with one of our key customers. Q4 2010 was much heavier. We had some shift of programming from Q3 to Q4 and then of course, we have the return of our support year-over-year from one of our key customers. So the combination of those two led to somewhat of a deceleration that you see.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I guess sort of what I really like if you could maybe compare and contrast a bit your efforts on managing the cost environment sort of this time around versus when you had to do it in 2008? I guess, you have weaker consumer I think but you've inv
componenttext: And then I guess sort of what I really like if you could maybe compare and contrast a bit your efforts on managing the cost environment sort of this time around versus when you had to do it in 2008? I guess, you have weaker consumer I think but you've invested a lot in your pants of the last couple of years are they in a better position -- I guess, can you price more, less or the same of your cost increases you're facing versus '08? Or in other words, just more of your productivity in Cadbury as sort of this time around need to be used to offset costs or less of them relative to last time?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I actually think we're in a stronger position to be able to price. I do think it's a weaker environment then, a weaker consumer environment particularly in a number of the developed markets around the world. But I think we're in a much stronger position.
componenttext: I actually think we're in a stronger position to be able to price. I do think it's a weaker environment then, a weaker consumer environment particularly in a number of the developed markets around the world. But I think we're in a much stronger position. Certainly, the fact of the investment that we've made in our brand franchises put us in a much stronger position. And it really makes our brands traffic builders for most of our retail partners. And so it's a key benefit for us to be able to work with them to be able to develop programming together that can help us to not only continue to grow our brands in our category, but also to be able to drive traffic to their stores. So in that sense, I think we're in a much stronger position to be able to talk about pricing. That said, we're not blindly pricing. We are certainly looking to bridge the price value impact of the pricing actions that we're taking. We have programs that we described the Huddle up for Hunger, a program that really allowed us to get strong merchandising support and also consumer value for a very important cost. In that case, hunger. We're looking at packaging option on a number of our businesses that will help us to somewhat mitigate the impact of the pricing action. But net-net, I think it's a weaker environment overall, but I think our portfolio is in a much stronger position than it was before at that time.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the last call, there were two issues that came up from my perspective: One, you just started to take price at the time. The competition hadn't really priced yet and you lost a little share. It seems like private level and matched that either. So i want
componenttext: On the last call, there were two issues that came up from my perspective: One, you just started to take price at the time. The competition hadn't really priced yet and you lost a little share. It seems like private level and matched that either. So i want an update there either sequentially from 3Q to 4Q or how you feel so far in 2011. And the second issue, which had to do with sort of your revenue expectations for the quarter and I guess it does have an impact for 2111 that one of your largest customers I guess, there was an issue about how fast they were kind of going to get things going again with the particular part of their store. And I'm just curious where we are there as well?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, again, we put the pricing that we talk to you about in the third quarter, and as we told you at that time, we expected to see some dislocation between the pricing and the cost. And because we are the leaders in the vast maturity of our category
componenttext: Yes. Well, again, we put the pricing that we talk to you about in the third quarter, and as we told you at that time, we expected to see some dislocation between the pricing and the cost. And because we are the leaders in the vast maturity of our category, we found that we were leading pricing in most of those categories. But the reality is, we continued to see costs going up for everyone and we expect that over the course of time, these price gaps will narrow. But we did not see any significant change in the fourth quarter in our price gaps versus key competition. So I feel very good about the strength of our brands and our ability to deliver value even in the face of a challenging economic environment. With respect to our key customer, our business is certainly improving. We feel very good about the performance in general and versus our competition. But I would tell you, it's still not where we needed to be, and we continue to work with them on marketing and merchandising ideas that would make sense for both of us. As an example, we're going to be running a Meal Solutions program in about two weeks that helps to drive traffic through their stores and enables them to merchandise a number of their center aisle items. And so I think business is coming back. We feel very good about the performance in the fourth quarter. We're up in a high single digits. But we still believe there is room for continued growth as we work together to not only deal with the consumer environment, but to help to drive store traffic.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: Tim, on the cost inflation for 2011, just how much of it is locked in and how much of it isn't?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, we don't really talk about our hedged positions. But on balance, we are until we can price and on balance there. So there's typically about a quarter's worth of hedge position. Now that varies across geography because there are differen
componenttext: Well, as you know, we don't really talk about our hedged positions. But on balance, we are until we can price and on balance there. So there's typically about a quarter's worth of hedge position. Now that varies across geography because there are different dynamics to price. It also depends on the fair amount of the commodity category. For instance, there's not a very deep market in Cheese, and therefore, we tend to be a little less hedged than Cheese. Meats, we tend to be a little shorter on. Some of the problem that we had in the quarter as one of the key ones that have less hedged positions are ran up considerably in the quarter. But our hedged position is about what it usually is on an ongoing basis.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, Irene, the organic sales growth was very good in the fourth quarter, and that was with the consumer weakness and with the pricing that you've began to take to try to get to catch up with the inflation. So I guess, one, would you agree with that?
componenttext: And then, Irene, the organic sales growth was very good in the fourth quarter, and that was with the consumer weakness and with the pricing that you've began to take to try to get to catch up with the inflation. So I guess, one, would you agree with that? Was the elasticities better than you thought and does that give you some more confidence in terms of pricing? And if you could just  add some color in terms of maybe Europe, U.S. and Developing Markets in terms of the ability to price there and what some of the dynamics are?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We were very pleased with our fourth quarter results for a whole bunch of reasons. The aggregate result we felt pretty good about. I feel particularly good about the composition of the revenue drivers. As we said, about 70% came from vol/mix, but 30%
componenttext: Yes. We were very pleased with our fourth quarter results for a whole bunch of reasons. The aggregate result we felt pretty good about. I feel particularly good about the composition of the revenue drivers. As we said, about 70% came from vol/mix, but 30% from pricing so we feel very good about that balance. And as we look at what the drivers of that work, it was again, I think, good management of our brands. And we talk a lot about our continued investment in the face of some of the economic challenges in a number of markets. We had a number of very strong programs, for example, in North America in the fourth quarter. We talked about the Huddle to Fight Hunger, we had the new advertising and on a number of our key franchises, Planters nuts , Chips Ahoy!, Mac and Cheese a number of our Power Brands that really served us very, very well. And we have a nice roster of new products that we started to introduce in the fourth quarter, things like Oscar Mayer Carving Board and we had some good new biscuit alternatives. So in general, we feel good about our ability, and that's really why I, as the answer I said to Andrew earlier, we feel good about our ability to take price in the face of some of these challenging economic conditions. As we think about Europe, I feel very good about the continued top line momentum again in the face of some of the challenging economic situation. And as you saw, we had some disproportionate results depending upon the various countries. But overall, we had a good balance of vol/mix and pricing, we've got broad-based business momentum in our Developing Markets I think the -- we feel very good about our ability to continue to grow our Power Brands with the investments and despite the inflation. And so overall, we feel quite good about the performance in the quarter, and we believe it bodes well for the momentum into 2011.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Terry Bivens from JP Morgan.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, just on the North American unit, did you quantify how much -- see the operating earnings were down there. Did I miss how much they were actually down? Can we get some measure on that?
componenttext: Tim, just on the North American unit, did you quantify how much -- see the operating earnings were down there. Did I miss how much they were actually down? Can we get some measure on that?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. The earnings are down about $100 million versus last year in North America. To give you a rough rundown of that, we had favorable vol/mix that contributed about $30 million to $35 million. We were unfavorable of the price cost relationship to the tun
componenttext: Yes. The earnings are down about $100 million versus last year in North America. To give you a rough rundown of that, we had favorable vol/mix that contributed about $30 million to $35 million. We were unfavorable of the price cost relationship to the tune of $175 million. For our gross margins were depressed by the net of that. Spent a little bit more on AMC as we continue to invest in our brands, but as I mentioned, we managed the overhead and have contributed about $50 million of favorability. So the North America cost us about $0.04 a quarter year-on-year.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Irene, for you, clearly this a challenging year and certainly, commodities have jumped ahead of where people thought they would be. But in terms of the earnings guidance, as indicated, it is short to kind of a more bullish posture. You attributed that
componenttext: And Irene, for you, clearly this a challenging year and certainly, commodities have jumped ahead of where people thought they would be. But in terms of the earnings guidance, as indicated, it is short to kind of a more bullish posture. You attributed that I guess, to the vol/mix first of all. But if I could export that just a little bit more, how about marketing? Where do you think marketing should be this year? Might you ramp that up? And perhaps the commodity element out of it as well, I'm just trying to get a better sense of the  caution there I guess.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I feel very good about our 2011 program and I think you'll have an opportunity to get a lot more visibility today at CAGNY. As I look across the innovation pipeline, it's a strong buy plan, we've got strong support behind our items and I think that w
componenttext: Yes, I feel very good about our 2011 program and I think you'll have an opportunity to get a lot more visibility today at CAGNY. As I look across the innovation pipeline, it's a strong buy plan, we've got strong support behind our items and I think that will be an important driver. We've got some good momentum on our Power Brands as we've said, and I really feel quite confident. As I said, the impact of lesser contributions from vol/mix will have some impact on our earnings, but I feel quite confident that we have a number of levers that are going to enable us to deliver the guidance that we've laid out. We start up with the fact that Cadbury turns accretive in 2011. We will have lower interest expense from the retirement of our debt and we've got very strong cost savings program that began to kick in the fourth quarter that will continue into 2011 coming from both growth procurement and as well as overhead efficiency that will -- it should help us to drive the business. So I feel quite comfortable with the guidance that we're giving. That said, obviously, Easter is going to be in the second quarter this year, and so it will make the comps difficult in the first quarter. But I'm quite comfortable by the first half, we will be on the trend that we've laid out.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Moskow of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of numbers on the guidance, Tim, I have the finishing the year with a 27% tax rate. Is the guidance for a higher tax rate in 2011? And then secondly, I had interest expense down about $100 million for 2011. Am I pretty close on those two thi
componenttext: Just a couple of numbers on the guidance, Tim, I have the finishing the year with a 27% tax rate. Is the guidance for a higher tax rate in 2011? And then secondly, I had interest expense down about $100 million for 2011. Am I pretty close on those two things?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tax rate, yes, Rob. We ended this year at 27.3%. Remember, we benefited from a change in the U.K. tax rate, and we had a settlement earlier in the year of the significant third of time back in 2002, 2004 timeframe and that drove our rate down. Next year,
componenttext: Tax rate, yes, Rob. We ended this year at 27.3%. Remember, we benefited from a change in the U.K. tax rate, and we had a settlement earlier in the year of the significant third of time back in 2002, 2004 timeframe and that drove our rate down. Next year, we would expect it to be right around 30%. And your number on interest is probably pretty close.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then also on Starbucks, are you guiding to significantly lower earnings in this? Is that part of your guidance here on Starbucks? Because you're not shipping anymore. And when will we -- and obviously you can't figure out when the proceeds are coming,
componenttext: And then also on Starbucks, are you guiding to significantly lower earnings in this? Is that part of your guidance here on Starbucks? Because you're not shipping anymore. And when will we -- and obviously you can't figure out when the proceeds are coming, but how are you going to treat that? Would it be discontinued at some point?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, to start up, we still are shipping. We still have the business. Starbucks has no intent to take it back March 1. But as of right now, we're still fully shipping. You know we lost the first round of our preliminary downturn, but we have a field that
componenttext: Well, to start up, we still are shipping. We still have the business. Starbucks has no intent to take it back March 1. But as of right now, we're still fully shipping. You know we lost the first round of our preliminary downturn, but we have a field that and that will still be played out. We've asked for treatment so we will know before March 1 as to whether we will be granted that. We have not reflected any change to our guidance with any assumption that Starbucks businesses is going to go away.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: So this guidance assumes a full year of Starbucks sales?
componenttext: So this guidance assumes a full year of Starbucks sales?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does.
componenttext: Yes, it does.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Isn't that a little aggressive, Tim?
componenttext: Isn't that a little aggressive, Tim?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I been quite frankly at this point, it's nothing that really have and we still have a contract with Starbucks. And I mean, they have notified their intent, and we would argue that we still have a contract in place. So at this point, I think it would be pr
componenttext: I been quite frankly at this point, it's nothing that really have and we still have a contract with Starbucks. And I mean, they have notified their intent, and we would argue that we still have a contract in place. So at this point, I think it would be prudent to assume that they're going to continue. Should that change, certainly you'll know about it.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Diane Grice Diane Geissler with CL estate.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Diane Grice Diane Geissler with CL estate.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just have a question on your top line guidance and if you covered this, my apologies. But the 4% top line growth, you had two quarters now where you've had some pricing. Do you have a break on what your expectations are for 2011 on vol/mix versus pricin
componenttext: I just have a question on your top line guidance and if you covered this, my apologies. But the 4% top line growth, you had two quarters now where you've had some pricing. Do you have a break on what your expectations are for 2011 on vol/mix versus pricing within the 4%?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said, Diane , we exited this year about 2/3 70%, 30% it will likely be the reverse as we look at the environment in 2007. So we expect about 2/3 of it coming from pricing, about 1/3 that will come from vol/mix..
componenttext: Well, as we said, Diane , we exited this year about 2/3 70%, 30% it will likely be the reverse as we look at the environment in 2007. So we expect about 2/3 of it coming from pricing, about 1/3 that will come from vol/mix..

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: But you do expect volume growth in 2011?
componenttext: But you do expect volume growth in 2011?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes we do, and we believe we've got some very strong programming, as well as very strong brands around the world and we believe that, that together with our innovation pipeline and the revenue synergies that we will realize from the continued integration
componenttext: Yes we do, and we believe we've got some very strong programming, as well as very strong brands around the world and we believe that, that together with our innovation pipeline and the revenue synergies that we will realize from the continued integration of Cadbury will drive that vol/mix performance.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I guess just a follow-up question which touches on that topic, if you look at, in particular some of these emerging markets where food inflation has been running at rates higher than the U.S. and other developed markets, what is the risk to your
componenttext: And then I guess just a follow-up question which touches on that topic, if you look at, in particular some of these emerging markets where food inflation has been running at rates higher than the U.S. and other developed markets, what is the risk to your emerging markets strategy is there some kind of government intervention to put the brake on growth there? I mean, is that something that concerns you that just keep raising rates in China until growth slows and we have demand obstruction? Is that something that concerns you?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've done our best to take into account what we could see on the horizon. We certainly are working with the relevant governments around the world to ensure that we can adequately distribute our products at a fair price. But we have in place
componenttext: Well, I think we've done our best to take into account what we could see on the horizon. We certainly are working with the relevant governments around the world to ensure that we can adequately distribute our products at a fair price. But we have in place pleased with the performance in our Developing Markets and we are counting on contribution from that as we look forward. We are taking a fairly conservative view in the revenue guidance that we have given, we've taken a fairly conservative view on all of our markets around the world. We've given out long-term targets in each of the key regions, and we're looking to -- we're expecting performance probably at the lower end of those ranges in each of the geographies, including our Developing Markets for that reason.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you remind me what your guidance is for the emerging markets growth?
componenttext: Could you remind me what your guidance is for the emerging markets growth?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: 10 to 12 is the numbers we have laid out there.
componenttext: 10 to 12 is the numbers we have laid out there.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Alexia Howard of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: U.S. Coffee Business, we've seen, I guess, one is the major layers stuff of promotional activity quite substantially in the last month or so. Are you worried about the competitive dynamics? And clearly, volume growth is going to be important to you.
componenttext: U.S. Coffee Business, we've seen, I guess, one is the major layers stuff of promotional activity quite substantially in the last month or so. Are you worried about the competitive dynamics? And clearly, volume growth is going to be important to you.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I can't feel quite good about the performance of our Coffee Business, both in the quarter and on the year. We gained share in mainstream. I think we're making excellent progress in improving margins in that business. So we feel quite good about that healt
componenttext: I can't feel quite good about the performance of our Coffee Business, both in the quarter and on the year. We gained share in mainstream. I think we're making excellent progress in improving margins in that business. So we feel quite good about that health of the business. And I think we've got a good set of planned stage for 2011.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the U.K. Gum business, it looks as though from take away so that's down quite a bit right now right now. I'm assuming that chocolate is quite strong, but has there been a change is change of strategy about the U.K. government wins at the momen
componenttext: And then on the U.K. Gum business, it looks as though from take away so that's down quite a bit right now right now. I'm assuming that chocolate is quite strong, but has there been a change is change of strategy about the U.K. government wins at the moment or is it just flow out the pace of the new product construction?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean it's a relatively smaller business relative to most of our businesses and the key markets. The big strength of the U.K. this year, as he said, was Gum. But a lot of that has to do with some of the overall economic factors. A lot of our strengt
componenttext: Yes, I mean it's a relatively smaller business relative to most of our businesses and the key markets. The big strength of the U.K. this year, as he said, was Gum. But a lot of that has to do with some of the overall economic factors. A lot of our strength in the U.K. has do with the strength of chocolate. But we need to continue to take some actions to stimulate come in a number of key markets but we did suffer some share erosion in the U.K.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Driscoll of Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Driscoll of Citi Investment Research.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to explore the gross margin just a little bit further in the United States, or I suppose, North America. Tim , when you talked about this, I think it's an answers in some prior questions, you mentioned the fact that certain elements, Cheese and i
componenttext: I wanted to explore the gross margin just a little bit further in the United States, or I suppose, North America. Tim , when you talked about this, I think it's an answers in some prior questions, you mentioned the fact that certain elements, Cheese and in certain  meats that you were just unable to hedge. Are those two segments -- does that really account for the bulk of why fourth quarter deviated from your expectations and the margin came in lower?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the three commodities that we really ran up quite a lot in the quarter were Cheese, meat and coffee. And particularly, in the first two. I mean, Cheese, we typically are much shorter on the hedge because of the availability of the hedge market. And a
componenttext: Yes, the three commodities that we really ran up quite a lot in the quarter were Cheese, meat and coffee. And particularly, in the first two. I mean, Cheese, we typically are much shorter on the hedge because of the availability of the hedge market. And again, meat tends to be a pretty quick pass-through but just left is always behind. So between Cheese and meat, they were the bigger piece of the gross margin issue.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: The past, we've noticed that the Oscar Mayer business really is a tremendous operation for you and that you can pass prices through. Would stand a recent event that the difficulty in the fourth quarter doesn't translate into the first quarter that by the
componenttext: The past, we've noticed that the Oscar Mayer business really is a tremendous operation for you and that you can pass prices through. Would stand a recent event that the difficulty in the fourth quarter doesn't translate into the first quarter that by the time we're really now we should see full pass-through of the higher meat prices? Is that a fair statement?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would normally fact unless we continue to see escalation. I mean we are caught up to the pricing, but as meat prices continued, their a bit bouncy out there now. But I'd say, as I continue to back up, it would put us to price more.
componenttext: Yes, I would normally fact unless we continue to see escalation. I mean we are caught up to the pricing, but as meat prices continued, their a bit bouncy out there now. But I'd say, as I continue to back up, it would put us to price more.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: One final question on pricing in North America, just biscuits, can you talk about your announced pricing actions thus far on the biscuit operations?
componenttext: One final question on pricing in North America, just biscuits, can you talk about your announced pricing actions thus far on the biscuit operations?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't want to get into specific categories, as you might imagine, David. But once again, we have taken a number of steps on our biscuit business as a number of our key franchises to address the price value and to ensure that we have the brand strength
componenttext: We don't want to get into specific categories, as you might imagine, David. But once again, we have taken a number of steps on our biscuit business as a number of our key franchises to address the price value and to ensure that we have the brand strength to be able to address the current commodity environment.  We've got some innovative ideas like a fresh packaging format for Ritz, and premium, for example, that allows us to sell pressure but smaller packages to help the out-of-pocket, we've got some family sizes of Oreo and Chips Ahoy!. So we're taking a number of actions in that business, as well as across the portfolio to help bridge the challenging price million dollars burning. But we had a solid quarter in biscuit and I think we've got some good momentum on that business coming into the year.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Robert Dickerson of Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Robert Dickerson of Consumer Edge Research.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, the first question is -- I know you said before that we plan for fiscal year '11 was to spend back or I guess in general was to spend back about 25% of the cost savings in marketing. Has that changed?
componenttext: I guess, the first question is -- I know you said before that we plan for fiscal year '11 was to spend back or I guess in general was to spend back about 25% of the cost savings in marketing. Has that changed?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, that's right. The synergies that we generate in 2011, we expect to spend roughly 25% that's correct. That has not changed.
componenttext: No, that's right. The synergies that we generate in 2011, we expect to spend roughly 25% that's correct. That has not changed.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: If we saw 22% of the cost synergies coming through in fiscal 10, there really shouldn't be a net negative impact for fiscal '11. It's just a matter of timing and it's still flowing through into '11.
componenttext: If we saw 22% of the cost synergies coming through in fiscal 10, there really shouldn't be a net negative impact for fiscal '11. It's just a matter of timing and it's still flowing through into '11.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. Our synergies will step back up little bit in fiscal '11 relative to -- the 5% rate in 2010 and we expect to be 75% '11. If you were to quantify, it probably about $0.12 of growth synergies year-on-year improvement.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. Our synergies will step back up little bit in fiscal '11 relative to -- the 5% rate in 2010 and we expect to be 75% '11. If you were to quantify, it probably about $0.12 of growth synergies year-on-year improvement.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a little more of a strategic  question, just kind of what's happening in the marketplace with respect to retailers. I know obviously, you just said before that is a kind of increase your pricing more power within the stores, versus the Cadb
componenttext: And maybe just a little more of a strategic  question, just kind of what's happening in the marketplace with respect to retailers. I know obviously, you just said before that is a kind of increase your pricing more power within the stores, versus the Cadbury now that you are a partner with the retailer to help drive traffic. I mean,  there's a lot of food companies are seeing the us I'm just curious that you may have any type of additional competitive advantage just because of the level of marketing that you expect to put behind your products in 2011 relative to Gum position?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I believe so. I think as we look at category after category and the impact of our category has on driving traffic or actually in all of our markets around the world, I think it gives us a very strong position to have a conversation. Of course, you can ima
componenttext: I believe so. I think as we look at category after category and the impact of our category has on driving traffic or actually in all of our markets around the world, I think it gives us a very strong position to have a conversation. Of course, you can imagine the retailers are no happier about driving cost than we are. But I think the opportunity for us, because we have a broad portfolio, we have very, very strong iconic brands for the consumer, it gives us the opportunity to have discussions with them about snacking solutions, about meal solutions, about Huddle For Hunger programs and those sort of things and I feel very good about continuing to leverage capabilities in the U.S., our sales capabilities like wall-to-wall, which enable us then to merchandise a number of those products in stores. So I think we're bringing to our retailers preferred consumer brands. We have shown our ability to be able to help drive the category and drive traffic as a result of our marketing of those brands and I think that will continue to be a strength of our selling force in the partnership.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let's just assume, this is kind of a follow-up to Rob's question earlier, let's just assume that you do the Starbucks. I think you mentioned before that there is an agreement there as long as you have Starbucks, you can operate with any other global partn
componenttext: Let's just assume, this is kind of a follow-up to Rob's question earlier, let's just assume that you do the Starbucks. I think you mentioned before that there is an agreement there as long as you have Starbucks, you can operate with any other global partner. If you were to loose Starbucks, would there be a different growth strategy that may potentially already kind of be in the works?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the copies of $5 billion business for us globally in the core category of ours and we are committed to it. Certainly, in the U.S., continue to make significant investments in the business. As I mentioned a moment ago, we seen good progress in our ma
componenttext: Well, the copies of $5 billion business for us globally in the core category of ours and we are committed to it. Certainly, in the U.S., continue to make significant investments in the business. As I mentioned a moment ago, we seen good progress in our mainstream Coffee Business. We had a very strong year. And that we remained committed in the competing in the premium segment. So clearly, we will continue to compete in the premium segment but we're are not in liberty to discuss that any further as we sit here today.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Palmer of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Palmer of UBS.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, a quick follow-up on that Starbucks thing. If that happens, is that -- I would guess maybe $0.04 of earnings loss for the year if it happens March 1? I mean , could you give us a sense of how much of that could mean?
componenttext: First, a quick follow-up on that Starbucks thing. If that happens, is that -- I would guess maybe $0.04 of earnings loss for the year if it happens March 1? I mean , could you give us a sense of how much of that could mean?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a number of variables that will depend upon how it plays out. There is the direct cost of income, there any what the proceeds that we have received and the timing thereof, and it will be trend on our alternative premium strategy. So Starbucks
componenttext: Yes, there's a number of variables that will depend upon how it plays out. There is the direct cost of income, there any what the proceeds that we have received and the timing thereof, and it will be trend on our alternative premium strategy. So Starbucks, that business today for us, your number is probably a little bit low in terms of the earnings of that business historically. But it's very dependent upon all of those factors.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just a separate question on the Gum category, I think your language was that there is cyclical weakness that has hit that category globally? I would've thought that there was some element of the category cycling a pretty robust period of innovation. S
componenttext: And just a separate question on the Gum category, I think your language was that there is cyclical weakness that has hit that category globally? I would've thought that there was some element of the category cycling a pretty robust period of innovation. Some have described it as historically so. And then the majority of the issue is that and you're coming back and somewhat almost passed acknowledging that, that was the issue by saying you're coming back here in the first quarter with some more energy behind the category that suggest this is going to be a better year and not just subject to some macro conditions. I know it's probably tough to piece it all out, but what are your thoughts about hope for improvement this year?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: We are quite confident that we will swee improvement in 2011. There's no question that Gum was hurt disproportionately as I mentioned from the macroeconomic environment. It seems sort of a funny phenomenon because it's a little pack of Gum, but the facts
componenttext: We are quite confident that we will swee improvement in 2011. There's no question that Gum was hurt disproportionately as I mentioned from the macroeconomic environment. It seems sort of a funny phenomenon because it's a little pack of Gum, but the facts are the main users a lot of our sales come in the convenience stores. And so it's really -- it was hurt us proportionately, in particular in markets like Southern Europe, it was a big factor in our results there. In addition, as you could imaging there's a fair amount of spending came out of the category in the last 18 months or so given some of the M&A activity. Cadbury is in the heat of battle, had pulled back. We talk a lot about that actually at the time. And so we've been in the process of restoring the spending, as well as ensuring that we have a strong innovation pipeline. And on both of those counts, I feel quite good about the program that we have in 2011. We basically have -- we've seen terrific results in a number of markets, even in Q4, as we've started to reinvest behind the business in markets like Japan, where we were up double digits in the first quarter; markets like Brazil, where we had very strong performance; and even markets like South Africa, that were up double digits; and even markets like Russia, where we were still down, we're able to change the trend as a result of the investments. I feel quite confident that our investment in the category, together with what is a stronger pipeline at the start of the year, we've got Trident vitality coming out, we've got Strides Spark going up and we've got continued strength in events like Dentyne in the U.S. and Clorets in Japan. And so that's the reason we feel quite optimistic about the prospect in 2011 and we continue to see strong, long-term potentially in the Gum and Candy categories.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Eric Sirota with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next question comes from Eric Sirota with Wells Fargo.

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: You touched briefly on the year-on-year comparison for the  first quarter. You commented that gross margins would be under pressure in the first half. And you also commented on the Easter shift. Just want to make sure everyone is modeling this correctly.
componenttext: You touched briefly on the year-on-year comparison for the  first quarter. You commented that gross margins would be under pressure in the first half. And you also commented on the Easter shift. Just want to make sure everyone is modeling this correctly. Are you expecting your earnings to be up or down or flat as you look at the first quarter and first half?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would expect that year-on-year, we had a pretty strong quarter, first quarter of last year, relatively both the Easter shift and the margin pressure, it's in the strong quarter last year we'd expect probably EPS to be down a couple of cents. As we
componenttext: Yes, we would expect that year-on-year, we had a pretty strong quarter, first quarter of last year, relatively both the Easter shift and the margin pressure, it's in the strong quarter last year we'd expect probably EPS to be down a couple of cents. As we get that half and Easter normalizes and we start to pick up a little margin, we expect probably to be on a cent per share basis, about similar to what it was in the first half. So Eric, we can kind of build on that. If you think about earning seasonality across the quarters, in 2010 was quite a bit different and that a large portion of our earnings and earnings growth was in the first half of the year as opposed to the second half of the year. As you roll forward, keep in mind, in Q1, not only do you have the Easter shift, but we're going to have the full impact of the interest and shares outstanding from the Cadbury deal impact Q1 as well.  So you can kind of put it all together, you'd probably see a much more normalized distribution of earnings across the quarters this year, but because the comparison you may see we'll be down a couple of cents in the first quarter, but then you build from there.

componenttext: And it looks like you're reaching your deleveraging targets ahead of what we had anticipated, and I think ahead of your schedules as well. About getting to approximately 3x debt-to-EBITDA ratio a year from now, could you talk a bit about uses of cash once you get to that point? And are acquisitions potentially on the table, I know that back in September, Irene you made a comment that large acquisitions were not in the table for the foreseeable future given the Cadbury integration and the balance sheet. Could that perhaps have changed with the better than expected progress on both of those fronts?

headline: Kraft Foods Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll repeat that. We're very pleased with our cash flow  from 2010 and optimistic about 2011. We're very disciplined within the Kraft base business and we frankly saw a bigger opportunity than perhaps we had initially anticipated at Cadbury as we bring pa
componenttext: I'll repeat that. We're very pleased with our cash flow  from 2010 and optimistic about 2011. We're very disciplined within the Kraft base business and we frankly saw a bigger opportunity than perhaps we had initially anticipated at Cadbury as we bring particular their working capital back into line. So we had very strong generation year, it enabled us to deleverage a bit ahead of the schedule so we're continued to be pleased with that. We had said that we would be approaching the 3x number, which is the number we kind of targets to support our credit rating in the next 12 or so months. We may be a little bit ahead of that perhaps. And we'll evaluate at that time use of cash. I would say -- while we're  making very good progress on the integration as I Irene laid out in her presentation, but there's still a lot of work to be done. That's our primary focus. So exploring acquisitions right now is probably not on top of our priority list. And we'll explore share repurchases and dividends when the get our ratios underline.
